sen.j: 春日神（かすがのかみ）は、神道の神 (神道)である。
sen.e: Kasuga no kami is a deity of Shinto.
Kasuga no kami is a Shinto deity.
Kasuga no kami is a Shinto deity.

sen.j: 春日明神または春日権現とも称される。
sen.e: It is also known as 'Kasuga Myojin' or 'Kasuga Gongen.'
It is also known as 'Kasuga Myojin' or 'Kasuga Gongen.'
It is also known as 'Kasuga Myojin' or 'Kasuga Gongen.'

sen.j: 春日大社から勧請を受けた神のことである。
sen.e: Kasuga no kami refers to deities who were transferred from Kasuga Taisha Shrine through "kanjo" (ceremonial transfer of a divided tutelary deity to a new location).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Kasuga no kami refers to a deity who was transferred from Kasuga Taisha Shrine through "kanjo" (the ceremonial transfer of a divided tutelary deity to a new location).
Kasuga no kami refers to a deity who was transferred from Kasuga Taisha Shrine through "kanjo" (the ceremonial transfer of a divided tutelary deity to a new location).

sen.j: 神社の祭神を示すときに主祭神と並んで春日大神などと書かれる。
sen.e: When a shrine displays the name of a enshrined deity, the name of Kasuga no kami is also displayed as 'Kasuga Daijin' together with the main enshrined deity.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When a shrine displays the name of an enshrined deity, the name of the Kasuga no kami is also displayed as 'Kasuga Daijin' together with the main enshrined deity.
When a shrine displays the name of an enshrined deity, the name of the Kasuga no kami is also displayed as 'Kasuga Daijin' together with the main enshrined deity.

sen.j: 春日神を祀る神社は春日神社などという社名になっており、日本全国に約1000社ある。
sen.e: Shrines that enshrine Kasuga no kami are called 'Kasuga Jinja,' and there are 1,000 Kasuga-Jinja shrines nationwide.
Shrines that enshrine Kasuga no kami are called 'Kasuga Jinja,' and there are 1,000 Kasuga-Jinja shrines nationwide.
Shrines that enshrine Kasuga no kami are called 'Kasuga Jinja,' and there are about 1,000 Kasuga-Jinja shrines nationwide.

sen.j: 春日大社の祭神は以下の四柱の神であるので、春日神の本体は以下の四神ということになる。
sen.e: Because Kasuga Taisha Shrine enshrines the following four deities, these four deities are considered to embody the form of Kasuga no Kami.
Since Kasuga Taisha Shrine enshrines the following four deities, they are considered the embodiment of Kasuga no Kami.
Since Kasuga Taisha Shrine enshrines the following four deities, they are considered the embodiment of Kasuga no Kami.

sen.j: 天児屋命
sen.e: "Amenokoyane no Mikoto" (a legendary ancestor deity)
Amenokoyane no Mikoto
sen.cmt: Deleted the inverted commas and explantion as they don't really add anything
sen.e: Amenokoyane no Mikoto

sen.j: タケミカヅチ
sen.e: Takemikazuchi
Takemikazuchi
Takemikazuchi

sen.j: 経津主神
sen.e: Futsunushi no kami
Futsunushi no kami
Futsunushi no kami

sen.j: 比売神
sen.e: Hime no kami
Hime no kami
Hime no kami

sen.j: 春日神は藤原氏・中臣氏の氏神である。
sen.e: Kasuga no kami is "ujigami" (tutelary deity) of the Fujiwara and Nakatomi clans.
Kasuga no kami is an "ujigami" (tutelary deity) of the Fujiwara and Nakatomi clans.
Kasuga no kami is an "ujigami" (tutelary deity) of the Fujiwara and Nakatomi clans.

sen.j: ただし、春日大社にこの四神が祀られることになるのは768年のことで、それ以前の春日の地では榎本明神が祀られていた。
sen.e: The above-mentioned four deities came to be enshrined in Kasuga Taisha Shrine by 768; before that, Enomoto Myojin had been worshiped in the Kasuga region.
The above-mentioned four deities were enshrined in Kasuga Taisha Shrine by 768; before that, Enomoto Myojin had been worshiped in the Kasuga region.
The above-mentioned four deities were enshrined in Kasuga Taisha Shrine in 768; before that, Enomoto Myojin had been worshiped in the Kasuga region.
sen.cmt: 768年に祀られたので、in だと思います。

sen.j: 現在は春日大社の摂社の榎本神社に祀られている。
sen.e: Presently, Enomoto Myojin is enshrined in the "sessha" (auxiliary shrine (dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine)) of Kasuga Taisha Shrine.
Presently, Enomoto Myojin is enshrined in the "sessha" (auxiliary shrine) of Kasuga Taisha Shrine.
Presently, Enomoto Myojin is enshrined in the "sessha" (auxiliary shrine) of Kasuga Taisha Shrine.

sen.j: 江戸時代にサルタヒコのこととされるようになったが、それ以前は巨勢祝あるいは巨勢姫明神という神が祀られていた。
sen.e: During the Edo period, Enomoto Myojin was identified as Sarutahiko, but prior to this period, a deity called 'Kyose Iwai,' or a deity called 'Kyose Hime Myojin' had been worshiped.
During the Edo period, Enomoto Myojin was identified with Sarutahiko (leader of the Earthly Gods), but prior to that, a deity known as 'Kyose Iwai' or 'Kyose Hime Myojin' had been worshiped.
sen.cmt: Added explanation of who Sarutahiko was
sen.e: During the Edo period, Enomoto Myojin was identified with Sarutahiko (leader of the Earthly Gods), but prior to that, a deity known as 'Kose no Hafuri' or 'Kose no Hime Myojin' had been worshiped.
sen.cmt: 巨勢祝と巨勢姫明神の読み方、訂正

sen.j: この神は当地の地主神と考えられ、当地に基盤のあった春日氏の氏神とされる。
sen.e: This deity (Kyose Iwai or Kyose Hime Myojin) is considered an indigenous deity (ujigami) in the Kasuga region and regarded as the tutelary deity of the Kasuga clan, an ancient noble family who had a base in this region.

This deity (Kyose Iwai or Kyose Hime Myojin) is considered an indigenous deity (ujigami) of the Kasuga region and regarded as the tutelary deity of the Kasuga Clan, an ancient noble family who had a base in this region.

This deity (Kose no Hafuri or Kose no Hime Myojin) is considered an indigenous deity (ujigami) of the Kasuga region and regarded as the tutelary deity of the Kasuga Clan, an ancient noble family who had a base in this region.
sen.cmt: 巨勢祝と巨勢姫明神の読み方、訂正
